literature_search.ai_response:
## Recent papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus

Below are recent, relevant papers returned by a literature search for \synaptic plasticity hippocampus". For each item I include the citation, publication date, short summary (from the tool output), and a link you can follow to read or obtain the article. Where the tool returned an image URL I embedded it.

### 1) Editorial: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity at hippocampal and cortical synapses  
- Authors: Vitureira N., De Pasquale R., Leão R.M., Rossi F.M.  
- Published: 15 July 2022  
- Summary: Editorial introducing a Research Topic on cellular and molecular mechanisms (LTP, LTD, HSP, STDP) at hippocampal and cortical synapses. Discusses timescales of plasticity and relevance to development and memory.  
- Link / DOI: [Editorial: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity at hippocampal and cortical synapses](https://doi.org/10.3389/fncel.2022.980623)  
- Access: Open access (PDF available).

---

### 2) Synaptic plasticity and mental health: methods, challenges and opportunities  
- Authors: Lawrence G. Appelbaum et al.  
- Published: 17 Oct 2022 (Neuropsychopharmacology / review)  
- Summary: Review linking mechanisms of synaptic plasticity to mental health and psychiatric disease; discusses measurement techniques (imaging, neuromodulation), challenges and therapeutic opportunities.  
- Link: [Synaptic plasticity and mental health: methods, challenges and opportunities](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41386-022-01370-w.pdf?error=cookies_not_supported&code=34e16863-ac9f-4f45-8219-2ce69826f3af)  
- Access: PDF available via the provided link.

---

### 3) Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons  
- Author: Attila Losonczy (et al.)  
- Published: 18 Dec 2024 (Nature)  
- Summary: All-optical approach to monitor spine-level synaptic weight changes before/after induction of place fields in CA1 pyramidal neurons in behaving animals. Finds temporally asymmetric plasticity kernel and compartment-specific differences (basal vs oblique dendrites), linking synaptic plasticity to rapid emergence of spatial selectivity.  
- Link: [Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9?error=cookies_not_supported&code=99fed048-9696-4c0c-81ab-d1c517d6a190)  
- Image:  
  ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- Access: Preview available; institutional/subscription access may be required.

---

### 4) Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus  
- Author: Jeffrey C. Magee (et al.)  
- Published: 4 Jun 2025 (Nature Neuroscience)  
- Summary: Tracked CA1 place cells during a 7-day learning task. Shows progressive increase in number and stability of place cells; behavioral timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP) accompanies both formation and retrieval of place fields. Suggests CA1 memory emerges through increasing likelihood of neuron-specific plasticity rather than permanent weight stabilization.  
- Link: [Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)  
- Image:  
  ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- Access: PDF download link available from the page.

---

### 5) The Intriguing Contribution of Hippocampal Long-Term Depression to Spatial Learning and Long-Term Memory  
- Authors: M. Stacho & D. Manahan-Vaughan  
- Published: 25 Apr 2022 (Frontiers in Behavioral Neuroscience)  
- Summary: Review arguing LTD has specific roles in hippocampus-dependent learning and memory (pattern separation, pruning of synapses, interplay with LTP), beyond simply preventing saturation. Discusses electrophysiological and behavioral evidence in rodents.  
- Link / DOI: [Frontiers article (PDF)](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnbeh.2022.806356/pdf)  
- Access: Open access.

---

### 6) Modulation of hippocampal plasticity in learning and memory  
- Authors: Tanja Fuchsberger & Ole Paulsen  
- Published: 2022 (PubMed entry)  
- Summary: Review discussing how hippocampal synaptic plasticity is modulated during learning and memory, mechanisms and functional consequences (PubMed entry shown).  
- Link: [PubMed — Modulation of hippocampal plasticity in learning and memory](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35660989/)  
- Access: Use PubMed link for abstract; follow to full text where available.

---

Notes and next steps
- I can retrieve more recent or more specialized papers (e.g., BTSP, spine-level imaging, molecular signaling in LTP/LTD) if you tell me specific subtopics or date ranges.  
- If you want full-text extraction for any particular paper from the list (when publicly available), I can attempt to read the full article using the read-paper tool — tell me which one(s) and I will fetch the PDFs/text where possible.

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

The entitysdk examples show a convenient pattern using search_entity(...).all() to fetch results. If the SDK supports retrieving all with `.all()`, use that:

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# If the client supports .all() to fetch everything (with internal paging)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

print(f\Total morphologies returned: {len(morphs)}\")
for m in morphs[:10]:  # show first 10
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 4) Filtering examples (by mtype or species)

You can pass query filters to narrow results (examples from docs):

- Find morphologies for a specific MType label:

```python
morphs_sr_pc = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label\": \SR_PC\"}
).all()
```

- Limit by species (scientific name):

```python
morphs_mouse = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\subject__species__name\": \Mus musculus\"}
).all()
```

---

## Important Platform / EntityCore rules (summary)

- When calling GET ALL endpoints, mention and check `total_items`. Ask before using extra pages if you need to avoid large downloads.
- The EntityCore examples show `client.search_entity(...).all()` as a convenient approach; it may already page for you.
- The SDK examples in the repo demonstrate additional workflows: uploading assets, registering morphologies, adding MType classifications \u2014 see the entitysdk examples for full patterns.

---

If you\u2019d like:
- I can produce a ready-to-run script tailored to your auth method (API key / OAuth) \u2014 tell me which auth you use.
- Or I can show an example using explicit entitycore API parameters (page, page_size) adapted to the exact client methods you have \u2014 tell me which entitysdk version or client functions you see.
software_docs_entitysdk.ai_response:
## Quick guide: list all cell morphologies in Python with the entitysdk

Below are two practical approaches:

- Primary approach (SDK): using the entitysdk to fetch all cell morphologies.
- Fallback approach: simple REST example if you prefer direct HTTP requests or if the SDK isn’t available.

Note: You’ll need appropriate authentication (API key or token) and the correct base URL for your Open Brain Platform instance.

---

## 1) Using the entitysdk (preferred)

Prerequisites
- Install the SDK package (adjust the package name to the exact one you have in your environment):
  - Example: `pip install openbraininstitute-entitysdk` (or the exact package name provided by your platform)
- Have an API key or token ready
- Know your platform’s base URL (e.g., `https://api.openbrainplatform.org`)

Example code (typical SDK usage pattern)
- This is a concrete pattern you can adapt to the exact API surface of your SDK. If your SDK uses different method names, adjust accordingly.

```python
# Install in advance: pip install openbraininstitute-entitysdk

from openbraininstitute.entitysdk import EntitySDK  # adjust import if your package uses a different module path

# Initialize the client (adjust parameter names to your SDK)
client = EntitySDK(
    base_url=\https://api.openbrainplatform.org",  # replace with your instance
    api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\                       # or token, depending on the SDK
)

# Fetch all cell morphologies
# If the SDK uses a resource-like structure, this is a common pattern:
try:
    morphologies = client.cell_morphology.get_all(page=None, page_size=None)  # adjust to your SDK's API
    # If the SDK returns a list plus metadata, handle accordingly
    for m in morphologies.items:  # or morphologies, depending on the response shape
        print(f\ID: {m.id}, Name: {m.name}, Description: {m.description}")
        # Optional: print subject/species or other metadata if available
        if hasattr(m, \subject") and hasattr(m.subject, \species"):
            print(f\  Species: {m.subject.species.name}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f\Error retrieving morphologies: {e}")
```

Tips
- Pagination: if there are many morphologies, use `page` and `page_size` (e.g., `page=1, page_size=100`) and loop until you’ve exhausted all pages.
- Filtering: you can often filter by fields like name, species, brain region, or author. Check the SDK docs for exact filter parameters (e.g., `name__ilike`, `subject__species__name`, etc.).
- Response shape: some SDKs return a dict with `items` and `total_items`; others return a list. Adapt the iteration accordingly.

If you have the exact SDK documentation or a quick snippet of how the SDK exposes the cell morphology endpoint (e.g., method names, return types), I can tailor the code precisely.

---

## 2) RESTful alternative (using requests)

If you don’t have the SDK handy, you can list morphologies via a REST call.

Prerequisites
- Install requests: `pip install requests`
- Base URL and API key as above

Example:

```python
import requests

BASE_URL = \https://api.openbrainplatform.org\  # adjust
API_KEY = \YOUR_API_KEY"

headers = {
    \Authorization": f\Bearer {API_KEY}",
    \Accept": \application/json",
}

def list_cell_morphologies(page=1, page_size=100):
    url = f"{BASE_URL}/cell-morphologies\  # adjust to your actual endpoint path
    params = {\page": page, \page_size": page_size}
    resp = requests.get(url, headers=headers, params=params)
    resp.raise_for_status()
    return resp.json()

# Example usage
page = 1
while True:
    data = list_cell_morphologies(page=page, page_size=100)
    items = data.get(\items", data.get(\morphologies", []))
    for m in items:
        print(f\ID: {m.get('id')}, Name: {m.get('name')}, Description: {m.get('description')}")
    total = data.get(	otal_items", data.get(	otal", 0))
    if page * 100 >= total:
        break
    page += 1
```

- **Mtype:** **CBXpu_PuC** (Cerebellum Purkinje Cell)  
- **Description:** Soma flask-like (radius ≈ 7.5 µm) in Purkinje cell layer. Large, flat, highly-branched dendritic tree in molecular layer. Single long axon projecting downward to white matter — principal output of cerebellum.

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
## Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum — selected papers (2023–2025)

Below are several recent, high-impact studies that focus on neuronal morphology and whole-cell reconstructions in cerebral (cortical / prefrontal / visual / whole‑brain) contexts. I list the citation, a short summary of the main morphological findings, and a link to the paper (DOI/URL). Where the search tool returned a figure image URL I embedded it.

### 1) Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry (Peng et al., 2024)
- **Citation / Link:** [Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6)  
- **Summary:** Large-scale whole‑brain morphometry in mouse: registered 204 mouse brains to the Allen CCF, annotated ~182k cell bodies, modeled dendritic microenvironments and full morphology for ~1,876 neurons, and detected ~2.6M axonal varicosities. Multi-scale quantification of neuronal diversity and stereotypy across dendritic/axonal features and sub‑neuronal motifs. Major resource for morphological atlases and cross-scale analyses.
- **Image:**  
  ![Figure from Peng et al. 2024](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 2) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex (Ecker et al., 2025)
- **Citation / Link:** [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w)  
- **Summary:** Data-driven, graph‑based machine learning analysis of >30,000 excitatory neurons from MICrONS serial‑section EM volume (V1 and higher visual areas). Shows morphological variation is better represented as continuous axes rather than discrete m‑types, with laminar and inter‑area trends (e.g., layer‑specific tufting, dendritic width variation). Emphasizes continuum organization of dendritic morphologies.
- **Image:**  
  ![Figure from Ecker et al. 2025](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 3) Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy (Markram et al., eLife preprint, 2024)
- **Citation / Link:** [Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry — Anatomy (eLife preprint)](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/99688v1/pdf)  
- **Summary:** Data‑driven anatomical model of juvenile rat somatosensory cortex with 4.2M morphologically detailed neurons placed in atlas space and ~14.2B synapses (local, mid‑range, extrinsic). Emphasizes large‑scale morphological realism for circuit modeling and highlights limits/assumptions when deriving connectivity from anatomy alone.

### 4) Cell class‑specific long‑range axonal projections in mouse somatosensory cortices (Aronoff & Petersen, eLife preprint, 2024)
- **Citation / Link:** [Cell class‑specific long‑range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker‑related somatosensory cortices (eLife preprint)](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/97602v1/pdf)  
- **Summary:** Detailed morphological analyses of projection patterns from cell classes in whisker‑related S1/Ss; documents distinct long‑range axonal motifs for different cell classes and discusses implications for sensorimotor transformations.

### 5) Single‑neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex (Yan et al., 2023)
- **Citation / Link:** [Single‑neuron analysis of dendrites and axons — mouse PFC](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01339-y)  
- **Summary:** Complete dendrite and axon morphology for ~2,000 neurons in mouse PFC; identified ~24 dendritic subtypes among pyramidal neurons and characterized axonal projection motifs. Shows correspondence between dendritic/axonal morphology and putative network roles in intra‑column and inter‑region connectivity.
- **Image:**  
  ![Figure from Yan et al. 2023](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-023-01339-y/MediaObjects/41593_2023_1339_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 6) Neuronal wiring diagram of an adult brain (Murthy et al., 2024) — whole‑brain connectomics (Drosophila)
- **Citation / Link:** [Neuronal wiring diagram of an adult brain](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07558-y)  
- **Summary:** Although in Drosophila, this is a landmark whole‑brain neuron/ synapse reconstruction (139k neurons, 54.5M synapses) and demonstrates morphological + connectivity mapping at whole‑brain scale — useful as a methodological and conceptual reference for mammalian whole‑brain morphology/connectomics efforts.
- **Image:**  
  ![Figure from Murthy et al. 2024](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07558-y/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7558_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

## Would you like any of the following?
- I can attempt to fetch the full text (PDF) of any of the open/public papers above using the read‑paper tool — tell me which paper(s) to retrieve.
- I can produce a short table comparing dataset size, species, brain region, and key morphological metrics for a selected subset.
- I can search specifically for human or rat cerebral morphology studies, or for morphology linked to electrophysiology (morpho‑electrical types).

simulation_tutorial.expected_output:
Here is a tutorial on how to simulate on the platform, specifically for simulating a single neuron model:

How to Simulate a Single Neuron Model on the Platform
Access Virtual Lab:

From the homepage, click the "Go to Virtual Lab" button.
Manage Projects:

Click on "Projects" in the left menu to see your projects.
Create a project if none exists.
Ensure you have credits in your project; transfer credits from your virtual lab if needed.
Build a Single Neuron Model:

Click on the "Build" column in the left panel.
Click the "Build" button in the single neuron tile.
Name your model, optionally add a description.
Select the brain region (e.g., primary somatosensory area).
Click "Start building."
Select a 3D reconstructed morphology (M model) and an existing electrical model (E model).
Filter morphologies by type (e.g., L5 TPC-A for thick tufted layer 5 pyramidal neuron).
Select the appropriate E model matching the morphology.
Save the created morph-electric model (M E model).
Simulate the Neuron Model:

Go back to your project homepage.
Click on the "Simulate" tab, then "Single Neuron."
Find your neuron model or search by name.
Click your model and press "New Simulation."
In the simulation window, pan, rotate, and zoom the neuron morphology.
Set experiment and simulation parameters.
Choose predefined current injection protocols or customize current steps.
Add multiple recording locations by clicking on the morphology or using the "Add Recording" button.
Press "Simulate" to run the simulation.
View and Save Results:

The "Results" tab will display recordings from selected locations.
Save recordings or save them to the library for later access.
You can watch the full tutorial video here:
How to simulate a single neuron model (Video)

If you want, I can guide you through any specific step or help you start a simulation on the platform.
simulation_tutorial.ai_response:
## How to simulate on the platform

You can run simulations at different scales (single neuron, small microcircuits, synaptome-aware models, etc.). Here’s a practical workflow and what you’ll need to get started.

### 1) Decide the scope of your simulation
- **Single neuron simulations**: Examine intrinsic properties or a specific MeModel.
- **Small microcircuits**: 3–20 neurons with intrinsic connectivity + extrinsic inputs.
- **Synaptome-enabled simulations**: Include detailed synapse distributions and connectivity.
- **Whole-brain or region-scale simulations**: For larger-scale dynamics (advanced).

### 2) Identify the circuit to simulate
- Find the circuit ID (UUID) you want to simulate.
- If you don’t know it, I can help locate circuits by name or region.

### 3) Create a full simulation configuration
You don’t just specify incremental changes; you provide the complete desired final configuration. The platform has a specialized tool to generate the configuration JSON from a natural-language description.

- Tool: obione-generatesimulationsconfig
- Required inputs:
  - circuit_id: The UUID of the target circuit.
  - config_request: A complete description of the desired final configuration (all elements, including existing ones plus any additions/removals).

#### Example config_request structure
- Target circuit scale (e.g., \microcircuit\ or \single").
- Build category (e.g., \computational_model\ or \em_reconstruction").
- Model details (MeModel, morphology, synaptic types).
- Simulation parameters (time steps, duration, recording probes, stimulus protocol).
- Output preferences (which variables to save, file formats).
- Any changes to connectivity or population parameters.

Example snippet (textual description you’d pass to the tool):
- \Simulate circuit 123e... with scale 'microcircuit'. Use computational_model build. Include 12 neurons with one excitatory pool and one inhibitory pool. External drive: Poisson input at 5 Hz to each neuron. Record soma potential and spike times for all neurons for 2 seconds. Output: CSV of time, neuron_id, V_m, and spike events."

If you’d like, I can generate a full JSON config for you using the tool.

### 4) Generate the simulation configuration
- I’ll use the GenerateSimulationsConfig tool to produce a structured JSON config from your description.

### 5) Run the simulation
- Submit the generated config to the platform’s simulator.
- Track status (started, running, done, or error).
- Retrieve results when finished.

### 6) Analyze and visualize results
- Review time series, raster plots, population metrics, and any model-specific outputs.
- Compare against targets or hypotheses.
- If needed, tweak parameters and re-run.

---

## Quick-start options

- If you already know the circuit you want and can provide a brief description of the final configuration, I can:
  - Generate a full configuration via the tooling step.
  - Then launch the simulation and report back the status and results.

- If you’re unsure, tell me:
  - The circuit name or region (e.g., “CA1 hippocampus microcircuit”).
  - Your desired scale (single neuron, microcircuit, synaptome, etc.).
  - What you want to measure (membrane potential, spikes, synaptic currents, etc.).
  - Duration and any stimuli (current clamp, injected current profile, stochastic inputs).

---

## What I need from you to start

Please provide:
1) The circuit ID (UUID) or a name to resolve it.
2) A complete description of the desired final configuration (or at least the key elements you want included).
3) What outputs you want to save and the simulation duration.

If you’d like, I can propose a concrete starter config for a common case (e.g., 12-neuron microcircuit with excitatory/inhibitory populations and Poisson drive) and then generate the JSON for you.

software_docs_obione.user: Please show me a code example of how to create a single cell simulation using the obione package.
software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe

print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Single-cell simulation example using the `obi_one` package

Below is a minimal, end-to-end example that demonstrates how to create and validate a single-cell (single-neuron) simulation configuration with `obi_one`, select a ME-Model, add a current-clamp stimulus, record soma voltage, and prepare the simulation for execution. Replace the placeholder IDs and paths with your project-specific values.

> NOTE: fill in the ME-model ID and any project paths where indicated.

### Python example

```python
# Example: single_cell_simulation.py
import obi_one as obi

# 1) Select the ME-Model to simulate
# Replace with a real ME-Model UUID from EntityCore (or use a discovery step)
ME_MODEL_ID = "<YOUR_MEMODEL_UUID>"

# The ME-Model reference used in the single-neuron config
me_model_ref = obi.Reference(kind=\me_model", id=ME_MODEL_ID)  # pattern used in obi_one examples

# 2) Create simulation metadata (campaign info)
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\Single cell current clamp test",
    campaign_description=\Test single-cell response to somatic current steps"
)

# 3) Define timestamps / stimulation schedule
# here: single stimulus starting at 100.0 ms
timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(
    start_time=100.0,
    interval=1000.0,
    number_of_repetitions=1
)

# 4) Define the neuron set - single neuron (ID 0) for an ME-model single-cell simulation
# Two common patterns:
# - Use IDNeuronSet when simulating a list of neuron instances
single_neuron_set = obi.IDNeuronSet(neuron_ids=obi.NamedTuple(name=\single", elements=[0]))

# 5) Define a constant current clamp stimulus (somatic)
i_stim = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=timestamps.ref,
    neuron_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    duration=200.0,       # ms
    amplitude=0.3,        # nA
    timestamp_offset=0.0
)

# 6) Define recordings - soma voltage
voltage_rec = obi.SomaVoltageRecording(
    timestamps=timestamps.ref,
    neuron_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    start_time=0.0,
    end_time=500.0
)

# 7) Build single-neuron simulation configuration
# There are multiple config builders in obi_one; use the single-neuron config form/pattern
single_conf = obi.SingleNeuronSimulationConfig.empty_config()  # typical factory pattern in obi_one

single_conf.set(info, name=\info")
single_conf.add(single_neuron_set, name=\SingleNeuronSet")
single_conf.add(timestamps, name=\Timestamps")
single_conf.add(i_stim, name=\IStimulus")
single_conf.add(voltage_rec, name=\VoltageRecording")

# Attach the ME-model reference (model to be instantiated for the single neuron)
# The precise mechanism can be either part of Initialize or a top-level field depending on version:
initialize = obi.SingleNeuronSimulationConfig.Initialize(
    me_model=me_model_ref,
    node_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    simulation_length=single_conf.records()[\VoltageRecording"].end_time if hasattr(single_conf, ecords") else 500.0
)
single_conf.set(initialize, name=\initialize")

# 8) Validate the configuration (ensures required pieces are present)
validated_conf = single_conf.validated_config()

# 9) (Optional) Run the simulation via obi_one runtime (or export config for remote runner)
# Two common patterns:
# - Local runner:
runner = obi.SingleNeuronRunner()
result = runner.run(validated_conf)

# - Or export config and submit to your platform's simulation service
# validated_conf.to_json(\single_neuron_conf.json")

# 10) Inspect / save results
# Example result access pattern (depends on runtime):
if result.status == \success":
    traces = result.get_voltage_traces()  # API names vary; check runner's return object
    # traces typically a dict: {neuron_id: { 	imestamps": [...], \voltage": [...] } }
    print(\Simulation finished, traces available for neuron 0")
else:
    print(\Simulation failed:", result.status)
```

### Key steps and mapping to `obi_one` components
- **ME-Model selection**: supply an ME-model UUID (from EntityCore). You can discover ME-Models using the EntityCore search API or the examples that list available ME-Models.
- **Timestamps**: use `RegularTimestamps` to schedule stimulation windows.
- **Neuron set**: for a single-cell simulation use an `IDNeuronSet` with a single element (often 0) or the appropriate pattern used by your ME-model runner.
- **Stimulus**: `ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus` injects current at soma (supports scalar or scan vectors).
- **Recordings**: `SomaVoltageRecording` to capture membrane potential.
- **Configuration**: use the SingleNeuron config factory, attach initialize block with the ME-model and node set, validate, then run or export.
- **Execution**: either run locally with an obi_one runner (if available) or export and submit to your compute environment.
